title: What is the best old skool hip-hop record? - Quora

response.answer_text: In m opinion these are the top 3 best rap albums of all time in no order: Efil4ZagginSlightly mysoginistic.Too many skits and long intros.Introduced G-Funk in the mainstream.Kind of dark, and intentionally messy, but a masterpiece.IllmaticNo complaints, but not crazy in any aspect.Villain in BlackInsane lyricism, and very dark.G-Funk type beats.Here’s a song on each: N.W.A. - Niggaz4Life  I rate this song 10/10. The whole song is loaded with wordplay, facts, cases of racial profiling, and reality. This song discusses why N.W.A. call themselves “Niggaz Wit’ Attitudes,” and will continue to call themselves “niggaz” ’til they die (even though Real Niggaz Don’t Die). Each verse tells a new story or reason, similar to a debate with the public who disagrees with their logic. “Why do I call myself a nigga you ask me? Because police always wanna harass me Every time that I'm rollin They swear up and down that the car was stolen Make me get face down in the street And throw the shit out my car on the concrete In front of a residence A million white motherfuckers on my back like I shot the President” Nas - Halftime  Personally, I’d say this is the best song on Illmatic, but others don’t agree. This song sounds fantastic, it’s got great delivery, and dope lyricism. Out of 10, I’d give it a flat 9/10. “I used to hustle, now all I do is relax and strive When I was young I was a fan of the Jackson 5 I drop jewels, wear jewels, hope to never run it With more kicks than a baby in a mother's stomach” MC Ren feat. Bigg Rocc - Mind Blown  This song Ren displays great flow, lyricism, and has a similar sound to What’s Beef? by the Notorious B.I.G. This track I give a 9.5/10, because it’s dug very deep. It predicts that the rap game will be filled with artists who don’t put effort in their songs—who just dream one night of being a rapper and drop a song the next morning—Ren describes how he tortures them in his distinct, dark, lair. “I'm shockin motherfuckers like water and a live wire Makin niggas feel the fire like Richard Pryor The Great Elephant, the Bitch Made Nigga Killa I'm steppin’ on you niggas like a Godzilla” That’s what I think. Obviously, music is subjective. Hope I helped.

Best is pretty subjective so you’re bound to get a gazillion answers. If you mean single (and not album), one of the most impressive (and underrated) singles ever issued on Sugarhill Records was The Mean Machine’s “Disco Dream” (1981). The composition is tight, the rhymes are on time, and the recording captures the spirit of audience participation which, at that point, was a hallmark of the scene as it had been developing. Peace!
